questions.question: How did Texas Instruments' strategic emphasis on embedded processing products evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this 3-year progression indicate about the company's long-term positioning in the semiconductor industry?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Texas Instruments (TXN) consistently emphasized embedded processing products as a core pillar of its business model, highlighting them in each year's 10-K filing as central to its four sustainable competitive advantages. In 2022, embedded processing was described as a key part of the company's broad product portfolio, offering more opportunity per customer and greater value on investments. This focus remained unchanged in 2023, with the same language used to describe the competitive advantage derived from embedded processing products. By 2024, the company continued to reinforce this strategic direction, maintaining that embedded processing contributes to its unique positioning in the semiconductor market by supporting customer diversity, channel reach, and long-term investment returns. The consistent emphasis across all three years indicates a stable, long-term strategy centered on embedded processing as a foundational element for generating free cash flow and maintaining competitive differentiation.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [Embedded Processing Products]: Embedded processing products are described as a core component of the company’s business model and competitive advantages, particularly in expanding customer opportunity and investment value.

Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [Embedded Processing Products]: The strategic importance of embedded processing is reaffirmed, with identical language used to describe its role in delivering per-customer value and supporting long-term capital allocation decisions.

Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [Embedded Processing Products]: Embedded processing remains a central theme in the company’s strategy, with continued emphasis on its role in enabling TI to maintain a unique competitive position in the semiconductor industry.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## ITEM 7. Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations

## Overview

We design, make and sell semiconductors to electronics designers and manufacturers all over the world. Technology is the foundation of our company, but ultimately, our objective and the best metric to measure progress and generate long-term value for owners is the growth of free cash flow per share.

Our strategy to maximize free cash flow per share growth has three elements:

1. A great business model that is focused on analog and embedded processing products and built around four sustainable competitive advantages. The four sustainable competitive advantages are powerful in combination and provide tangible benefits:
- i. A strong foundation of manufacturing and technology that provides lower costs and greater control of our supply chain.
- ii. A broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offers more opportunity per customer and more value for our investments.
- iii. The reach of our market channels that gives access to more customers and more of their design projects, leading to the opportunity to sell more of our products into each design and gives us better insight and knowledge of customer needs.
- iv. Diversity and longevity of our products, markets and customer positions that provide less single point dependency and longer returns on our investments.

Together, these competitive advantages help position TI in a unique class of companies capable of generating and returning significant amounts of cash for our owners. We make our investments with an eye towards longterm strengthening and leveraging of these advantages.

2. Discipline in allocating capital to the best opportunities. This spans how we select R&D projects, develop new capabilities like TI.com, invest in new manufacturing capacity or how we think about acquisitions and returning cash to our owners.
3. Efficiency, which means constantly striving for more output for every dollar spent.

We believe that our business model with the combined effect of our four competitive advantages sets TI apart from our peers and will for a long time to come. We will invest to strengthen our competitive advantages, be disciplined in capital allocation and stay diligent in our pursuit of efficiencies. Finally, we will remain focused on the belief that long-term growth of free cash flow per share is the ultimate measure to generate value.

Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A) should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the related notes that appear elsewhere in this document. In the following discussion of our results of operations:

- Our segments represent groups of similar products that are combined on the basis of similar design and development requirements, product characteristics, manufacturing processes and distribution channels, and how management allocates resources and measures results. See Note 1 to the financial statements for more information regarding our segments.
- When we discuss our results:
- Unless otherwise noted, changes in our revenue are attributable to changes in customer demand, which are evidenced by fluctuations in shipment volumes.
- New products do not tend to have a significant impact on our revenue in any given period because we sell such a large number of products.
- From time to time, our revenue and gross profit are affected by changes in demand for higher-priced or lower-priced products, which we refer to as changes in the 'mix' of products shipped.

## Overview

We	design	and	manufacture	semiconductors	that	we	sell	to	electronics	designers	and	manufacturers	all	over	the	world. Technology	is	the	foundation	of	our	company,	but	ultimately,	our	objective	and	the	best	metric	for	owners	to	measure	our progress	is	through	the	growth	of	free	cash	flow	per	share	over	the	long	term.

Our	strategy	to	maximize	long-term	free	cash	flow	per	share	growth	has	three	elements:

Together,	these	competitive	advantages	help	position	TI	in	a	unique	class	of	companies	capable	of	generating	and returning	significant	amounts	of	cash	for	our	owners.	We	make	our	investments	with	an	eye	towards	long-term strengthening	and	leveraging	of	these	advantages.

2. Discipline	in	allocating	capital	to	the	best	opportunities.	This	spans	how	we	select	R&D	projects,	develop	new capabilities	like	TI.com,	invest	in	new	manufacturing	capacity	or	how	we	think	about	acquisitions	and	returning	cash	to our	owners.
3. Efficiency,	which	means	constantly	striving	for	more	output	for	every	dollar	spent.

We	believe	that	our	business	model	with	the	combined	effect	of	our	four	competitive	advantages	sets	TI	apart	from	our	peers and	will	for	a	long	time	to	come.	We	will	invest	to	strengthen	our	competitive	advantages,	be	disciplined	in	capital allocation	and	stay	diligent	in	our	pursuit	of	efficiencies.	Finally,	we	will	remain	focused	on	the	belief	that	long-term growth	of	free	cash	flow	per	share	is	the	ultimate	measure	to	generate	value.

Management's	discussion	and	analysis	of	financial	condition	and	results	of	operations	(MD&A)	should	be	read	in	conjunction with	the	financial	statements	and	the	related	notes	that	appear	elsewhere	in	this	document.	In	the	following	discussion	of our	results	of	operations:

See	Note	1	to	the	financial	statements	for	more	information	regarding	our	segments.
- When	we	discuss	our	results:
- Unless	otherwise	noted,	changes	in	our	revenue	are	attributable	to	changes	in	customer	demand,	which	are	evidenced by	fluctuations	in	shipment	volumes.
- New	products	do	not	tend	to	have	a	significant	impact	on	our	revenue	in	any	given	period	because	we	sell	such	a large	number	of	products.
- From	time	to	time,	our	revenue	and	gross	profit	are	affected	by	changes	in	demand	for	higher-priced	or	lower-priced products,	which	we	refer	to	as	changes	in	the	'mix'	of	products	shipped.

questions.question: How did Texas Instruments' aggregate expense for U.S. defined contribution plans evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year trend indicate about the company's investment in employee retirement benefits?
questions.answer: Texas Instruments' aggregate expense for U.S. defined contribution plans increased from $70 million in 2022 to $75 million in 2023, and remained stable at $76 million in 2024. This indicates a steady and slightly growing commitment to employee retirement benefits over the three-year period, with a total increase of approximately 8.6% from 2022 to 2024.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: U.S. defined contribution plan expense was $63 million in 2021 (mentioned in 2022 filing), showing baseline funding levels.
Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: U.S. defined contribution plan expense rose to $75 million in 2023, indicating increased investment in retirement benefits.
Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: U.S. defined contribution plan expense slightly increased to $76 million in 2024, showing continued support with a stable trend.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## 7. Postretirement benefit plans

## Plan descriptions

We have various employee retirement plans, including defined contribution, defined benefit and retiree health care benefit plans. For qualifying employees, we offer deferred compensation arrangements.

## U.S. retirement plans

Our principal retirement plans in the United States are a defined contribution plan, an enhanced defined contribution plan and qualified and non-qualified defined benefit pension plans. The defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997, and then current participants were allowed to make a one-time election to continue accruing a benefit in the plans or to cease accruing a benefit and instead to participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan.

Both defined contribution plans offer an employer-matching savings option that allows employees to make pretax and post-tax contributions to various investment choices. Employees who elected to continue accruing a benefit in the qualified defined benefit pension plans may also participate in the defined contribution plan, where employer-matching contributions are provided for up to 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees who elected not to continue accruing a benefit in the defined benefit pension plans and employees hired after November 1997 and through December 31, 2003, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. This plan provides for a fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings, plus an employer-matching contribution of up to 4% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees hired after December 31, 2003, do not receive the fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings.

As of December 31, 2021 and 2020, as a result of employees' elections, TI's U.S. defined contribution plans held shares of TI common stock totaling 6 million shares and 7 million shares valued at $1.16 billion and $1.12 billion, respectively. Dividends paid on these shares in both 2021 and 2020 were $27 million. Effective April 1, 2016, the TI common stock fund was frozen to new contributions or transfers into the fund.

Our aggregate expense for the U.S. defined contribution plans was $63 million in 2021 and $61 million in 2020 and 2019.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## 7.	Postretirement	benefit	plans

## Plan	descriptions

We	have	various	employee	retirement	plans,	including	defined	contribution,	defined	benefit	and	retiree	health	care	benefit plans.	For	qualifying	employees,	we	offer	deferred	compensation	arrangements.

## U.S.	retirement	plans

Our	principal	retirement	plans	in	the	United	States	are	a	defined	contribution	plan,	an	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan and	qualified	and	non-qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plans.	The	defined	benefit	plans	were	closed	to	new	participants	in 1997,	and	then	current	participants	were	allowed	to	make	a	one-time	election	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	plans	or to	cease	accruing	a	benefit	and	instead	to	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.

Both	defined	contribution	plans	offer	an	employer-matching	savings	option	that	allows	employees	to	make	pretax	and	post-tax contributions	to	various	investment	choices.	Employees	who	elected	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	qualified	defined benefit	pension	plans	may	also	participate	in	the	defined	contribution	plan,	where	employer-matching	contributions	are provided	for	up	to	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees	who	elected	not	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in the	defined	benefit	pension	plans	and	employees	hired	after	November	1997	and	through	December	31,	2003,	may	participate	in the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	This	plan	provides	for	a	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual eligible	earnings,	plus	an	employer-matching	contribution	of	up	to	4%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees hired	after	December	31,	2003,	do	not	receive	the	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible earnings.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	shares	of	TI common	stock	totaling	5	million	shares	and	6	million	shares	valued	at	$873	million	and	$940	million,	respectively.	Dividends paid	on	these	shares	in	2023	and	2022	were	$27	million	and	$28	million,	respectively.	Effective	April	1,	2016,	the	TI	common stock	fund	was	frozen	to	new	contributions	or	transfers	into	the	fund.

Our	aggregate	expense	for	the	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	was	$75	million	in	2023,	$70	million	in	2022	and	$63	million	in 2021.

The	defined	benefit	pension	plans	include	employees	still	accruing	benefits,	as	well	as	employees	and	participants	who	no longer	accrue	service-related	benefits,	but	instead,	may	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	Benefits under	the	qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plan	are	determined	using	a	formula	based	on	years	of	service	and	the	highest five	consecutive	years	of	compensation.	We	intend	to	contribute	amounts	to	this	plan	to	meet	the	minimum	funding	requirements of	applicable	local	laws	and	regulations,	plus	such	additional	amounts	as	we	deem	appropriate.	The	non-qualified	defined benefit	plans	are	unfunded	and	closed	to	new	participants.

## U.S.	retiree	health	care	benefit	plan

U.S.	employees	who	meet	eligibility	requirements	are	offered	medical	coverage	during	retirement.	We	make	a	contribution toward	the	cost	of	those	retiree	medical	benefits	for	certain	retirees	and	their	dependents.	The	contribution	rates	are	based upon	various	factors,	the	most	important	of	which	are	an	employee's	date	of	hire,	date	of	retirement,	years	of	service	and eligibility	for	Medicare	benefits.	The	balance	of	the	cost	is	borne	by	the	plan's	participants.	Employees	hired	after January	1,	2001,	are	responsible	for	the	full	cost	of	their	medical	benefits	during	retirement.

## Non-U.S.	retirement	plans

We	provide	retirement	coverage	for	non-U.S.	employees,	as	required	by	local	laws	or	to	the	extent	we	deem	appropriate, through	a	number	of	defined	benefit	and	defined	contribution	plans.	Retirement	benefits	are	generally	based	on	an	employee's years	of	service	and	compensation.	Funding	requirements	are	determined	on	an	individual	country	and	plan	basis	and	are subject	to	local	country	practices	and	market	circumstances.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	non-U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	TI common	stock	valued	at	$34	million	and	$33	million,	respectively.	Dividends	paid	on	these	shares	of	TI	common	stock	in	2023 and	2022	were	not	material.

questions.question: How did Texas Instruments' (TXN) operational footprint in Melaka, Malaysia evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this 3-year progression reveal about the company's focus on analog versus embedded processing in that location?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Texas Instruments maintained its operational presence in Melaka, Malaysia, consistently focusing solely on analog product lines without expanding into embedded processing. In 2022, Melaka was listed with an 'X' under Analog but not under Embedded Processing. This pattern remained unchanged in 2023 and 2024, indicating a stable, analog-only operational strategy in Melaka throughout the three-year period. This consistency suggests a targeted investment in analog capabilities rather than a diversification into embedded processing in that location.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → Melaka, Malaysia: Operates in Melaka with a focus on Analog (marked with 'X'), but not in Embedded Processing.
Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → Melaka, Malaysia: Continues to operate in Melaka with Analog marked ('X'), maintaining the same absence in Embedded Processing.
Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → Melaka, Malaysia: Operational focus remains unchanged in Melaka with Analog marked ('X'), and no addition to Embedded Processing.

questions.question: How did the availability of shares under the Texas Instruments 2003 Director Compensation Plan evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this trend indicate about TI's ongoing use of this plan for director compensation?
questions.answer: The availability of shares under the Texas Instruments 2003 Director Compensation Plan decreased from 2022 to 2024, indicating a gradual phase-out of the plan in favor of newer compensation vehicles. In 2022, the 2003 Director Compensation Plan was still referenced as active, with shares being issued under it. By 2023, the plan was no longer listed among those with remaining shares available for future issuance, though it was still referenced for outstanding grants. In 2024, the 2003 plan was no longer mentioned as part of the active compensation structure, with TI focusing on the 2024 LTIP and 2018 Director Plan for future awards. This reflects a strategic shift toward updated incentive structures while honoring existing commitments.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: Shares were still being issued under the 2003 plan, indicating it was active and part of the compensation structure.

Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: The 2003 plan was no longer listed among those with remaining shares available for future issuance, though it was still referenced for outstanding grants.
Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: The 2003 plan was no longer mentioned as part of the active compensation structure, with TI focusing on the 2024 LTIP and 2018 Director Plan.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
(a) Includes shares of TI common stock to be issued under the Texas Instruments 2003 Director Compensation Plan, the Texas Instruments 2009 Long-Term Incentive Plan (the '2009 LTIP') and its predecessor stockholder-approved plans, the Texas Instruments 2009 Director Compensation Plan, the TI Employees 2014 Stock Purchase Plan (the '2014 ESPP') and the Texas Instruments 2018 Director Compensation Plan (the '2018 Director Plan').

(b) Restricted stock units and stock units credited to directors' deferred compensation accounts are settled in shares of TI common stock on a one-for-one basis. Accordingly, such units have been excluded for purposes of computing the weighted-average exercise price.

(c) Shares of TI common stock available for future issuance under the 2009 LTIP, the 2014 ESPP and the 2018 Director Plan. 35,385,153 shares remain available for future issuance under the 2009 LTIP and 1,843,134 shares remain available for future issuance under the 2018 Director Plan. Under the 2009 LTIP and the 2018 Director Plan, awards may be granted in the form of restricted stock units, options or other stock-based awards such as restricted stock.

questions.question: How did the relative importance of the PC & Notebooks segment within Texas Instruments' Personal Electronics market evolve from 2022 to 2024, based on its revenue contribution and product composition across those years?
questions.answer: The importance of the PC & Notebooks segment within Texas Instruments' Personal Electronics market declined from 2022 to 2024. In 2022, Personal Electronics accounted for 24% of TI revenue, with PC & Notebooks listed among several subcategories. By 2023, the Personal Electronics segment had dropped to 15% of TI revenue, and in 2024, it rebounded slightly to 20% of revenue. Despite this partial recovery, the 2024 listing of PC & Notebooks was included alongside a growing number of other product categories, suggesting a diluted focus on PCs relative to other electronics. This indicates a downward trend in the strategic emphasis on PC & Notebooks over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2022) → [PC & Notebooks]: PC & Notebooks was part of the Personal Electronics segment, which represented 24% of TI revenue in 2022.
Hop 2: [TXN](2023) → [PC & Notebooks]: In 2023, the Personal Electronics segment dropped to 15% of TI revenue, with PC & Notebooks still listed as a key component.

Hop 3: [TXN](2024) → [PC & Notebooks]: By 2024, the Personal Electronics segment rose to 20% of TI revenue, but PC & Notebooks was listed among a broader set of product categories, indicating a less concentrated focus.

questions.question: How did Texas Instruments' strategic emphasis on embedded processing products evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this consistent positioning reveal about its long-term growth strategy centered on free cash flow per share?
questions.answer: Texas Instruments has consistently emphasized embedded processing products as a core component of its business model across 2022, 2023, and 2024, framing them as a key driver in achieving long-term growth in free cash flow per share. In 2022, the company highlighted the tangible benefits of its four competitive advantages, including a broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offer more opportunity per customer and more value for investments. In 2023, TI reiterated this strategic focus, underscoring that embedded processing products are central to its unique business model and long-term investment decisions. In 2024, the company maintained this narrative, emphasizing that embedded processing products continue to be foundational in leveraging its competitive advantages and guiding capital allocation. This consistent emphasis reveals that TI views embedded processing as a stable, high-margin, and scalable segment that supports its long-term objective of maximizing free cash flow per share.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2023) → Embedded Processing Products: Reaffirmed embedded processing as central to its business model and long-term investment decisions.
Hop 2: [TXN](2024) → Embedded Processing Products: Maintained strategic focus, emphasizing embedded processing as foundational to leveraging competitive advantages.
Hop 3: [TXN](2022) → Embedded Processing Products: Positioned embedded processing as a key element of its four competitive advantages and value creation.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## ITEM	7.	Management's	discussion	and	analysis	of	financial	condition	and	results	of	operations

## Overview

We	design	and	manufacture	semiconductors	that	we	sell	to	electronics	designers	and	manufacturers	all	over	the	world. Technology	is	the	foundation	of	our	company,	but	ultimately,	our	objective	and	the	best	metric	for	owners	to	measure	our progress	is	through	the	growth	of	free	cash	flow	per	share	over	the	long	term.

Our	strategy	to	maximize	long-term	free	cash	flow	per	share	growth	has	three	elements:

1. A	great	business	model	that	is	focused	on	analog	and	embedded	processing	products	and	built	around	four	sustainable competitive	advantages.	The	four	sustainable	competitive	advantages	are	powerful	in	combination	and	provide	tangible benefits:
2. (a)				A	strong	foundation	of	manufacturing	and	technology	that	provides	lower	costs	and	greater	control	of	our	supply chain.
3. (b)				A	broad	portfolio	of	analog	and	embedded	processing	products	that	offers	more	opportunity	per	customer	and	more value	for	our	investments.
4. (c)				The	reach	of	our	market	channels	that	gives	access	to	more	customers	and	more	of	their	design	projects,	leading to	the	opportunity	to	sell	more	of	our	products	into	each	design	and	gives	us	better	insight	and	knowledge	of customer	needs.
5. (d)				Diversity	and	longevity	of	our	products,	markets	and	customer	positions	that	provide	less	single	point dependency	and	longer	returns	on	our	investments.

Together,	these	competitive	advantages	help	position	TI	in	a	unique	class	of	companies	capable	of	generating	and returning	significant	amounts	of	cash	for	our	owners.	We	make	our	investments	with	an	eye	towards	long-term strengthening	and	leveraging	of	these	advantages.

2. Discipline	in	allocating	capital	to	the	best	opportunities.	This	spans	how	we	select	R&D	projects,	develop	new capabilities	like	TI.com,	invest	in	new	manufacturing	capacity	or	how	we	think	about	acquisitions	and	returning	cash	to our	owners.
3. Efficiency,	which	means	constantly	striving	for	more	output	for	every	dollar	spent.

We	believe	that	our	business	model	with	the	combined	effect	of	our	four	competitive	advantages	sets	TI	apart	from	our	peers and	will	for	a	long	time	to	come.	We	will	invest	to	strengthen	our	competitive	advantages,	be	disciplined	in	capital allocation	and	stay	diligent	in	our	pursuit	of	efficiencies.	Finally,	we	will	remain	focused	on	the	belief	that	long-term growth	of	free	cash	flow	per	share	is	the	ultimate	measure	to	generate	value.

Management's	discussion	and	analysis	of	financial	condition	and	results	of	operations	(MD&A)	should	be	read	in	conjunction with	the	financial	statements	and	the	related	notes	that	appear	elsewhere	in	this	document.	In	the	following	discussion	of our	results	of	operations:

- Our	segments	represent	groups	of	similar	products	that	are	combined	on	the	basis	of	similar	design	and	development requirements,	product	characteristics,	manufacturing	processes	and	distribution	channels,	and	how	management	allocates resources	and	measures	results.	See	Note	1	to	the	financial	statements	for	more	information	regarding	our	segments.
- When	we	discuss	our	results:
- Unless	otherwise	noted,	changes	in	our	revenue	are	attributable	to	changes	in	customer	demand,	which	are	evidenced by	fluctuations	in	shipment	volumes.
- New	products	do	not	tend	to	have	a	significant	impact	on	our	revenue	in	any	given	period	because	we	sell	such	a large	number	of	products.
- From	time	to	time,	our	revenue	and	gross	profit	are	affected	by	changes	in	demand	for	higher-priced	or	lower-priced products,	which	we	refer	to	as	changes	in	the	'mix'	of	products	shipped.

## ITEM 7. Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations

## Overview

We design and manufacture semiconductors that we sell to electronics designers and manufacturers all ov er the world. Technology is the foundation of our company, but ultimately, our objectiv e and the best metric for owners to measure our progress is through the growth of free cash flow per share ov er the long term.

Our strategy to maximize long-term free cash flow per share growth has three elements:

1. A great business model that is focused on analog and embedded processing products and built around four sustainable competitiv e adv antages. The four sustainable competitiv e adv antages are powerful in combination and prov ide tangible benefits:
2. (a)    A strong foundation of manufacturing and technology that prov ides lower costs and greater control of our supply chain.
3. (b)    A broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offers more opportunity per customer and more v alue for our inv estments.
4. (c)    T he reach of our market channels that giv es access to more customers and more of their design projects, leading to the opportunity to sell more of our products into each design and giv es us better insight and knowledge of customer needs.
5. (d)    Div ersity and longev ity of our products, markets and customer positions that prov ide less single point dependency and longer returns on our inv estments.

Together, these competitiv e adv antages help position TI in a unique class of companies capable of generating and returning significant amounts of cash for our owners. We make our inv estments with an eye towards long-term strengthening and lev eraging of these adv antages.

2. Discipline in allocating capital to the best opportunities. This spans how we select R&D projects, dev elop new capabilities, inv est in manufacturing capacity or how we think about acquisitions and returning cash to our owners.
3. Efficiency, which means constantly striv ing for more output for ev ery dollar spent.

We believe that our business model with the combined effect of our four competitiv e adv antages sets TI apart from our peers and will for a long time to come. We will inv est to strengthen our competitiv e adv antages, be disciplined in capital allocation and stay diligent in our pursuit of efficiencies. Finally, we will remain focused on the belief that long-term growth of free cash flow per share is the ultimate measure to generate v alue.

Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A) should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the related notes that appear elsewhere in this document. In the following discussion of our results of operations:

- Our segments represent groups of similar products that are combined on the basis of similar design and dev elopment requirements, product characteristics, manufacturing processes and distribution channels, and how management allocates resources and measures results. See Note 1 to the financial statements for more information regarding our segments.
- When we discuss our results:
- Unless otherwise noted, changes in our rev enue are attributable to changes in customer demand, which are ev idenced by fluctuations in shipment volumes.
- New products do not tend to hav e a significant impact on our rev enue in any giv en period because we sell such a large number of products.
- From time to time, our rev enue and gross profit are affected by changes in demand for higher-priced or lower-priced products, which we refer to as changes in the 'mix' of products shipped.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## ITEM 7. Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations

## Overview

We design, make and sell semiconductors to electronics designers and manufacturers all over the world. Technology is the foundation of our company, but ultimately, our objective and the best metric to measure progress and generate long-term value for owners is the growth of free cash flow per share.

Our strategy to maximize free cash flow per share growth has three elements:

1. A great business model that is focused on analog and embedded processing products and built around four sustainable competitive advantages. The four sustainable competitive advantages are powerful in combination and provide tangible benefits:
- i. A strong foundation of manufacturing and technology that provides lower costs and greater control of our supply chain.
- ii. A broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offers more opportunity per customer and more value for our investments.
- iii. The reach of our market channels that gives access to more customers and more of their design projects, leading to the opportunity to sell more of our products into each design and gives us better insight and knowledge of customer needs.
- iv. Diversity and longevity of our products, markets and customer positions that provide less single point dependency and longer returns on our investments.

Together, these competitive advantages help position TI in a unique class of companies capable of generating and returning significant amounts of cash for our owners. We make our investments with an eye towards longterm strengthening and leveraging of these advantages.

2. Discipline in allocating capital to the best opportunities. This spans how we select R&D projects, develop new capabilities like TI.com, invest in new manufacturing capacity or how we think about acquisitions and returning cash to our owners.
3. Efficiency, which means constantly striving for more output for every dollar spent.

We believe that our business model with the combined effect of our four competitive advantages sets TI apart from our peers and will for a long time to come. We will invest to strengthen our competitive advantages, be disciplined in capital allocation and stay diligent in our pursuit of efficiencies. Finally, we will remain focused on the belief that long-term growth of free cash flow per share is the ultimate measure to generate value.

Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A) should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the related notes that appear elsewhere in this document. In the following discussion of our results of operations:

- Our segments represent groups of similar products that are combined on the basis of similar design and development requirements, product characteristics, manufacturing processes and distribution channels, and how management allocates resources and measures results. See Note 1 to the financial statements for more information regarding our segments.
- When we discuss our results:
- Unless otherwise noted, changes in our revenue are attributable to changes in customer demand, which are evidenced by fluctuations in shipment volumes.
- New products do not tend to have a significant impact on our revenue in any given period because we sell such a large number of products.
- From time to time, our revenue and gross profit are affected by changes in demand for higher-priced or lower-priced products, which we refer to as changes in the 'mix' of products shipped.

questions.question: How has the value of TI common stock held in U.S. defined contribution plans evolved from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year trend indicate about the company's stock performance and employee investment behavior in retirement plans?
questions.answer: The value of TI common stock held in U.S. defined contribution plans decreased from $940 million in 2022 to $873 million in 2023, and further declined to $852 million in 2024. This consistent decline over three years suggests either a strategic reduction in stock allocations by employees, a freeze on new contributions into the TI common stock fund since 2016, or a combination of both, while also reflecting potential market valuation shifts.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TXN](2023) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: In 2023, U.S. defined contribution plans held 5 million shares of TI common stock valued at $873 million.
Hop 2: [TXN](2024) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: In 2024, the same plans held 5 million shares valued at $852 million, showing a slight decrease from the prior year.

Hop 3: [TXN](2022) → [Non-Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plan]: In 2022, U.S. defined contribution plans held 6 million shares valued at $940 million, indicating a reduction in both share count and value by 2023.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## 7.	Postretirement	benefit	plans

## Plan	descriptions

We	have	various	employee	retirement	plans,	including	defined	contribution,	defined	benefit	and	retiree	health	care	benefit plans.	For	qualifying	employees,	we	offer	deferred	compensation	arrangements.

## U.S.	retirement	plans

Our	principal	retirement	plans	in	the	United	States	are	a	defined	contribution	plan,	an	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan and	qualified	and	non-qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plans.	The	defined	benefit	plans	were	closed	to	new	participants	in 1997,	and	then	current	participants	were	allowed	to	make	a	one-time	election	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	plans	or to	cease	accruing	a	benefit	and	instead	to	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.

Both	defined	contribution	plans	offer	an	employer-matching	savings	option	that	allows	employees	to	make	pretax	and	post-tax contributions	to	various	investment	choices.	Employees	who	elected	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in	the	qualified	defined benefit	pension	plans	may	also	participate	in	the	defined	contribution	plan,	where	employer-matching	contributions	are provided	for	up	to	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees	who	elected	not	to	continue	accruing	a	benefit	in the	defined	benefit	pension	plans	and	employees	hired	after	November	1997	and	through	December	31,	2003,	may	participate	in the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	This	plan	provides	for	a	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual eligible	earnings,	plus	an	employer-matching	contribution	of	up	to	4%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible	earnings.	Employees hired	after	December	31,	2003,	do	not	receive	the	fixed	employer	contribution	of	2%	of	the	employee's	annual	eligible earnings.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	shares	of	TI common	stock	totaling	5	million	shares	and	6	million	shares	valued	at	$873	million	and	$940	million,	respectively.	Dividends paid	on	these	shares	in	2023	and	2022	were	$27	million	and	$28	million,	respectively.	Effective	April	1,	2016,	the	TI	common stock	fund	was	frozen	to	new	contributions	or	transfers	into	the	fund.

Our	aggregate	expense	for	the	U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	was	$75	million	in	2023,	$70	million	in	2022	and	$63	million	in 2021.

The	defined	benefit	pension	plans	include	employees	still	accruing	benefits,	as	well	as	employees	and	participants	who	no longer	accrue	service-related	benefits,	but	instead,	may	participate	in	the	enhanced	defined	contribution	plan.	Benefits under	the	qualified	defined	benefit	pension	plan	are	determined	using	a	formula	based	on	years	of	service	and	the	highest five	consecutive	years	of	compensation.	We	intend	to	contribute	amounts	to	this	plan	to	meet	the	minimum	funding	requirements of	applicable	local	laws	and	regulations,	plus	such	additional	amounts	as	we	deem	appropriate.	The	non-qualified	defined benefit	plans	are	unfunded	and	closed	to	new	participants.

## U.S.	retiree	health	care	benefit	plan

U.S.	employees	who	meet	eligibility	requirements	are	offered	medical	coverage	during	retirement.	We	make	a	contribution toward	the	cost	of	those	retiree	medical	benefits	for	certain	retirees	and	their	dependents.	The	contribution	rates	are	based upon	various	factors,	the	most	important	of	which	are	an	employee's	date	of	hire,	date	of	retirement,	years	of	service	and eligibility	for	Medicare	benefits.	The	balance	of	the	cost	is	borne	by	the	plan's	participants.	Employees	hired	after January	1,	2001,	are	responsible	for	the	full	cost	of	their	medical	benefits	during	retirement.

## Non-U.S.	retirement	plans

We	provide	retirement	coverage	for	non-U.S.	employees,	as	required	by	local	laws	or	to	the	extent	we	deem	appropriate, through	a	number	of	defined	benefit	and	defined	contribution	plans.	Retirement	benefits	are	generally	based	on	an	employee's years	of	service	and	compensation.	Funding	requirements	are	determined	on	an	individual	country	and	plan	basis	and	are subject	to	local	country	practices	and	market	circumstances.

As	of	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	as	a	result	of	employees'	elections,	TI's	non-U.S.	defined	contribution	plans	held	TI common	stock	valued	at	$34	million	and	$33	million,	respectively.	Dividends	paid	on	these	shares	of	TI	common	stock	in	2023 and	2022	were	not	material.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## 7. Postretirement benefit plans

## Plan descriptions

We have various employee retirement plans, including defined contribution, defined benefit and retiree health care benefit plans. For qualifying employees, we offer deferred compensation arrangements.

## U.S. retirement plans

Our principal retirement plans in the United States are a defined contribution plan, an enhanced defined contribution plan and qualified and non-qualified defined benefit pension plans. The defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997, and then current participants were allowed to make a one-time election to continue accruing a benefit in the plans or to cease accruing a benefit and instead to participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan.

Both defined contribution plans offer an employer-matching sav ings option that allows employees to make pretax and post-tax contributions to v arious inv estment choices. Employees who elected to continue accruing a benefit in the qualified defined benefit pension plans may also participate in the defined contribution plan, where employer-matching contributions are prov ided for up to 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees who elected not to continue accruing a benefit in the defined benefit pension plans and employees hired after Nov ember 1997 and through December 31, 2003, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. This plan prov ides for a fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings, plus an employer-matching contribution of up to 4% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees hired after December 31, 2003, do not receiv e the fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings.

As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, as a result of employees' elections, TI's U.S. defined contribution plans held shares of TI common stock totaling 5 million shares in both periods v alued at $852 million and $873 million, respectiv ely. Div idends paid on these shares in 2024 and 2023 were $26 million and $27 million, respectiv ely. Effectiv e April 1, 2016, the TI common stock fund was frozen to new contributions or transfers into the fund.

Our aggregate expense for the U.S. defined contribution plans was $76 million, $75 million and $70 million in 2024, 2023 and 2022, respectiv ely.

The defined benefit pension plans include employees still accruing benefits, as well as employees and participants who no longer accrue serv ice-related benefits, but instead, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. Benefits under the qualified defined benefit pension plan are determined using a formula based on years of serv ice and the highest fiv e consecutiv e years of compensation. We intend to contribute amounts to this plan to meet the minimum funding requirements of applicable local laws and regulations, plus such additional amounts as we deem appropriate. The non-qualified defined benefit plans are unfunded and closed to new participants.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## 7. Postretirement benefit plans

## Plan descriptions

We have various employee retirement plans, including defined contribution, defined benefit and retiree health care benefit plans. For qualifying employees, we offer deferred compensation arrangements.

## U.S. retirement plans

Our principal retirement plans in the United States are a defined contribution plan, an enhanced defined contribution plan and qualified and non-qualified defined benefit pension plans. The defined benefit plans were closed to new participants in 1997, and then current participants were allowed to make a one-time election to continue accruing a benefit in the plans or to cease accruing a benefit and instead to participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan.

Both defined contribution plans offer an employer-matching savings option that allows employees to make pretax and post-tax contributions to various investment choices. Employees who elected to continue accruing a benefit in the qualified defined benefit pension plans may also participate in the defined contribution plan, where employer-matching contributions are provided for up to 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees who elected not to continue accruing a benefit in the defined benefit pension plans and employees hired after November 1997 and through December 31, 2003, may participate in the enhanced defined contribution plan. This plan provides for a fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings, plus an employer-matching contribution of up to 4% of the employee's annual eligible earnings. Employees hired after December 31, 2003, do not receive the fixed employer contribution of 2% of the employee's annual eligible earnings.

As of December 31, 2021 and 2020, as a result of employees' elections, TI's U.S. defined contribution plans held shares of TI common stock totaling 6 million shares and 7 million shares valued at $1.16 billion and $1.12 billion, respectively. Dividends paid on these shares in both 2021 and 2020 were $27 million. Effective April 1, 2016, the TI common stock fund was frozen to new contributions or transfers into the fund.

Our aggregate expense for the U.S. defined contribution plans was $63 million in 2021 and $61 million in 2020 and 2019.

questions.question: How did the number of shares available for future issuance under the 2003 Director Compensation Plan evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this trend suggest about Texas Instruments' use of this plan for director compensation over time?
questions.answer: The number of shares available for future issuance under the 2003 Director Compensation Plan steadily declined from 1,843,134 shares in 2022 to 1,786,785 shares in 2023, and further to 1,745,284 shares in 2024. This consistent reduction over the three-year period indicates that Texas Instruments has been actively utilizing the plan for director compensation, gradually depleting the available share pool. The trend suggests a sustained reliance on this plan as part of the company's executive and director incentive strategy.

Hop 3: [TXN](2022) → [2003 Director Compensation Plan]: 1,843,134 shares remain available for future issuance under the 2003 Director Compensation Plan.

questions.question: How did Cisco's interest rate exposure on its 3.50% Senior Note evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's borrowing costs over time?
questions.answer: In fiscal year 2022, Cisco reported an effective interest rate of 3.20% on the $500 million 3.50% Senior Note maturing in June 2025. By fiscal year 2023, the effective rate on this same note had increased to 6.38%, and in fiscal year 2024, it further rose to 6.66%. This indicates a significant increase in Cisco's borrowing costs on this instrument over the three-year period, reflecting either market rate increases or shifts in investor risk perception.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: CSCO(2022) → 3.50% Note: Reports effective rate of 3.20% on $500M note maturing in June 2025
Hop 2: CSCO(2023) → 3.50% Note: Reports effective rate of 6.38% on the same $500M note
Hop 3: CSCO(2024) → 3.50% Note: Reports effective rate of 6.66% on the continuing $500M note

questions.question: How did Cisco's financial exposure through total return swaps linked to deferred compensation evolve from fiscal years 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of realized gains or losses, and what does this progression indicate about the company's risk management or compensation strategy?
questions.answer: Cisco's financial exposure through total return swaps tied to deferred compensation shifted significantly across the three-year period. By fiscal 2023, this position improved to a gain of $58 million, and in fiscal 2024, the gain increased further to $91 million. This progression indicates a notable turnaround in the performance of these instruments, potentially reflecting improved market conditions or strategic adjustments in Cisco's deferred compensation design or hedging practices.

questions.question: How did Cisco's utilization of its 5.90% Note evolve from fiscal year 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of its total debt composition and effective interest rate, and what does this indicate about the company's long-term financing strategy?
questions.answer: Cisco's utilization of its 5.90% Note remained consistent at $2,000 million across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, with the effective interest rate holding steady at 6.11% throughout the period. However, the composition of Cisco's total debt changed significantly — total long-term debt increased from $8,416 million in 2022 to $19,621 million in 2024, while short-term debt decreased from $499 million to $488 million. This indicates that Cisco has been increasingly relying on long-term fixed-rate instruments, including the 5.90% Note, as part of a broader strategy to stabilize financing costs amid rising debt levels.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2022) → [5.90% Note]: Cisco disclosed $2,000 million outstanding for the 5.90% Note with an effective rate of 6.11%, forming part of $8,915 million total debt.
Hop 2: [CSCO](2023) → [5.90% Note]: Cisco maintained the same $2,000 million amount for the 5.90% Note at the same 6.11% effective rate, now within a larger total debt structure of $20,109 million.

Hop 3: [CSCO](2024) → [5.90% Note]: Cisco continued to report the 5.90% Note at $2,000 million with a 6.11% effective rate, as total debt reached $20,109 million, showing strategic consistency in leveraging this instrument.

questions.question: How did the performance of Cisco's available-for-sale debt investments impact other income (loss), net across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this three-year trend indicate about the volatility of these investments?
questions.answer: In fiscal 2022, Cisco disclosed its available-for-sale debt investments in detail, setting the baseline for these assets. In fiscal 2023, the company reported higher losses in these investments, contributing negatively to the 'other income (loss), net' line item. This negative impact persisted into fiscal 2024, where again, higher losses in available-for-sale debt investments were cited as a primary driver of the change in 'other income (loss), net,' despite partial offsets from equity investments and privately held investments. ## Provision	for	Income	Taxes

The	provision	for	income	taxes	resulted	in	an	effective	tax	rate	of	15.6%	for	fiscal	2024,	compared	with	17.7%	for	fiscal 2023.	 The	 net	 2.1	 percentage	 points	 decrease	 in	 the	 effective	 tax	 rate	 was	 primarily	 due	 to	 an	 increase	 in	 discrete	 tax benefits	relating	to	prior	year	return-to-provision	true	up	and	an	increase	in	stock-based	compensation	windfall	benefit.

For	a	full	reconciliation	of	our	effective	tax	rate	to	the	U.S.	federal	statutory	rate	of	21%	and	for	further	explanation	of our	provision	for	income	taxes,	see	Note	18	to	the	Consolidated	Financial	Statements.

questions.question: How has Cisco's approach to pay equity evolved from fiscal 2022 to fiscal 2024, particularly in terms of its analytics framework and the scope of compensation fairness under the White House Equal Pay Pledge?
questions.answer: Cisco's approach to pay equity has evolved significantly from fiscal 2022 to fiscal 2024. In 2022, Cisco introduced an innovative and inclusive analytics framework to evaluate its compensation system and test for pay parity, aiming to correct gaps when found. By 2023, the company expanded its pay parity program beyond base salary to include additional forms of compensation such as promotions, bonuses, and stock decisions, ensuring the program addressed all employees across the full spectrum of diversity. In 2024, Cisco maintained this expanded scope and continued to refine its analytics-driven approach, emphasizing global self-reported data collection to support fairness across all forms of compensation. This progression indicates a deepening commitment to comprehensive pay equity, moving from foundational parity checks to a more holistic, data-informed strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [CSCO](2022) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Introduced analytics framework to evaluate pay parity, focusing on identifying and correcting gaps.
Hop 2: [CSCO](2023) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Expanded pay parity program to include promotions, bonuses, and stock decisions, ensuring broader fairness across compensation types.
Hop 3: [CSCO](2024) → [White House Equal Pay Pledge]: Continued to refine analytics and incorporated global self-reported data to support fairness across all compensation dimensions.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

Our  Inclusive  Future Action  Office  is  focused  on  driving  impacts  through  our  strategic  actions  in  the African American/Black community, and these actions will be the blueprint for how we help address inequity in communities around the world in the future. We are creating actions that can be replicated and scaled and are designed to cover the full spectrum of diversity, inclusive of gender, generation, race, ethnicity, orientation, ability, nationality and background - the foundation of our Conscious Culture.

## Compensation and Benefits

Our total compensation philosophy is designed to attract, reward and retain talent. It provides market competitive, performancebased compensation aligned with each employee's contribution and impact to the value we drive to our customers, partners and stockholders. We reward and recognize our employees for effecting innovation, collaboration, profitability, and growth within our geographies, product lines, and functions.

Cisco has always been committed to compensating our employees fairly and equitably. We are a founding signer of the White House Equal Pay Pledge and the Parity.org pledge, and we are leading the charge to make fair pay a reality for all employees through the Employers for Pay Equity Consortium. We have also introduced an innovative and inclusive framework that provides us powerful analytics to evaluate our complex compensation system. For example, by using these powerful analytics, we are able to test for pay parity on a regular basis, and when gaps are found, we strive to correct them.

## Health & Well-being

We have an ongoing commitment to focus on the health, safety, and well-being of our employees. We provide our employees and their families high-quality, flexible and convenient benefits and resources for their physical, mental, and financial well-being. Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, employees have continually had to focus on how to balance careers and personal lives, all while managing their own physical, emotional, and financial health. We developed a COVID-19 response and recovery strategy with a focus on both physical and mental health, recognizing the need to create an environment where employees can speak openly about mental health. In fiscal 2022, we continued to offer employees 'A Day for Me,' which were paid days off that allowed for each individual to recharge and rest. We have moved towards a hybrid work model in certain countries, giving our employees the flexibility to work offsite or at onsite Cisco locations.

## Employee Development

We believe in open-ended, self-directed learning, understanding that each individual knows what skills and resources they need to succeed. We encourage employees to explore assignments outside of their daily work and encourage everyone to harness their strengths and improve the way we all work. Employees choose their own career paths and we support that choice by providing them with tools and resources to help them achieve their career goals.

## Employee Engagement

We believe that strong communication is key in our Conscious Culture. This communication includes regular, virtual all hands, which we refer to as a 'Cisco Check-In,' and weekly team leader check-ins, which we refer to as a 'Team Space Check-In.' Our regular virtual Cisco Check-Ins were initially launched with a focus on sharing medical information at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Cisco Check-Ins have since evolved into a forum where we can discuss much more with our employees, from business updates to social justice to physical and mental health.

In fiscal 2022, we have seen high level of employee engagement. For example, there were approximately 2.1 million Team Space Check-Ins  by  our  employees  in  fiscal  2022,  reflecting  87%  of  employees  submitting  Team  Space  Check-Ins.  Employees  also participate  in  our  global  Engagement  Pulse  Survey  and  the  Real  Deal  Survey.  These  surveys  allow  our  employees  to  provide confidential feedback on our culture, company strategy and trust in their direct leaders.

## Purpose Report

Additional information regarding Cisco's ESG initiatives and our people, as well as our workforce diversity data, can be found in our Purpose Report and related supplemental information, which are located on our ESG Reporting Hub at https://www.cisco.com/c/m/en\_us/about/csr/esg-hub.html. The contents of our Purpose Report and related supplemental information are not incorporated by reference into this Annual Report on Form 10-K or in any other report or document we file with the SEC.

## Table	of	Contents

Cisco	has	signed	the	CEO	Action	for	Diversity	&	Inclusion	Pledge.	The	CEO	Action	for	Diversity	&	Inclusion	Pledge	is	a	CEOdriven	pledge	to	drive	measurable	action	and	meaningful	change	in	advancing	diversity,	equity	and	inclusion	in	the	workplace. We	are	delivering	on	these	actions	by	accelerating	diversity	across	the	full-spectrum	of	diversity	-	including	gender,	age, race,	 ethnicity,	 sexual	 orientation,	 ability,	 nationality,	 religion,	 veteran	 status,	 background,	 culture,	 experience, strengths	and	perspectives.	At	Cisco,	it	starts	at	the	top:	As	of	July	27,	2024,	36%	of	our	Executive	Leadership	Team	(ELT) are	women	and	43%	are	diverse	in	terms	of	gender	or	ethnicity.

We	publish	certain	gender	diversity	and	ethnic	diversity	workforce	data	annually.	Across	our	global	company,	we	have	driven broad	improvements	in	overall	workforce	diversity.	Based	on	our	fiscal	2023	data,	our	global	employee	base	was	comprised	of 29%	 women,	 71%	 men	 and	 0.1%	 nonbinary,	 and	 our	 U.S.	 employee	 base	 was	 comprised	 of	 the	 following	 ethnicities:	 48.2% White/Caucasian,	 33.5%	 Asian,	 6.5%	 Hispanic/Latino,	 5.6%	 African	 American/Black,	 2.0%	 two	 or	 more	 races	 (not	 Hispanic	 or Latino),	 0.3%	 American	 Indian	 or	 Alaska	 Native,	 0.2%	 Native	 Hawaiian/Other	 Pacific	 Islander,	 and	 3.7%	 prefer	 to	 not	 to disclose/unknown.

With	respect	to	social	justice,	Cisco	has	been	partnering	across	the	globe	to	scale	and	amplify	our	positive	impact.	We	have published	our	Social	Justice	Beliefs	&	Actions,	which	is	our	blueprint	for	how	we	respond	to	injustice	and	address	inequity for	any	community.	We	are	creating	actions	that	can	be	replicated	and	scaled	and	are	designed	to	cover	the	full	spectrum	of diversity,	inclusive	of	gender,	generation,	race,	ethnicity,	sexual	orientation,	ability,	nationality,	and	background	-	which is	the	foundation	of	our	Conscious	Culture.	This	work	is	part	of	a	plan	for	Cisco	to	drive	transformational,	generational impact	for	vulnerable	communities.	Our	Social	Justice	Action	Office	helps	drive	accountability,	progress,	and	excellence	in our	strategic	actions	in	this	area,	which	are	designed	to	address	the	broader	ecosystem	including	our	employees,	partners, customers,	and	suppliers.

## Compensation	and	Benefits

Our	 total	 compensation	 philosophy	 is	 designed	 to	 attract,	 reward,	 and	 retain	 talent.	 It	 provides	 market	 competitive, performance-based	compensation	aligned	with	each	employee's	contribution	and	impact	to	the	value	we	drive	to	our	customers, partners	and	stockholders.	We	reward	and	recognize	our	employees	for	effecting	innovation,	collaboration,	profitability,	and growth	within	our	geographies,	product	lines,	and	functions.

Cisco	has	always	been	committed	to	compensating	our	employees	fairly	and	equitably.	We	are	a	founding	signatory	of	the	White House	Equal	Pay	Pledge	and	the	Parity.org	pledge,	and	are	a	leader	in	the	charge	to	make	fair	pay	a	reality	for	all	employees through	the	Employers	for	Pay	Equity	Consortium.	We	have	also	introduced	an	innovative	and	inclusive	framework	that	provides us	powerful	analytics	to	evaluate	our	complex	compensation	system.	For	example,	by	using	these	powerful	analytics,	we	are able	to	test	for	pay	parity	on	a	regular	basis,	and	when	gaps	are	found,	we	strive	to	correct	them.

As	part	of	our	Social	Justice	Beliefs	and	Actions,	we	have	expanded	our	pay	parity	program	beyond	base	salary	to	include additional	forms	of	compensation	fairness	such	as	promotion,	bonuses,	and	stock	decisions	made	in	our	rewards	programs.	We aim	 to	 ensure	 the	 program	 addresses	 all	 employees	 across	 the	 full	 spectrum	 of	 diversity	 incorporating	 our	 global	 selfreported	data	collection.

## Health	&	Well-being

We	 have	 an	 ongoing	 commitment	 to	 focus	 on	 the	 health,	 safety,	 and	 well-being	 of	 our	 employees.	 We	 seek	 to	 provide	 our employees	and	their	families	with	high-quality,	flexible,	and	convenient	benefits	and	resources	for	their	physical,	mental, and	financial	well-being.	We	strive	to	support	our	employees	as	they	balance	careers	and	personal	lives,	as	well	as	their	own physical,	emotional,	and	financial	health.	We	continue	to	emphasize	a	focus	on	both	physical	and	mental	health,	recognizing the	need	to	create	an	environment	where	employees	can	speak	openly	about	mental	health	and	other	matters.

We	host	ongoing	discussions	with	our	employees	during	the	Cisco	Beat	and	Cisco	Check-Ins,	our	regular	company-wide	virtual meetings,	 and	 continue	 to	 emphasize	 our	 Safe	 to	 Talk	 program.	 We	 offer	 mindfulness	 courses,	 employee	 assistance	 program offerings,	and	out-of-network	provider	benefits	for	substance	abuse	and	mental	health	treatment,	and	more.	In	fiscal	2024,	we continued	to	offer	employees	'A	Day	for	Me,'	which	were	paid	days	off	that	allowed	for	each	individual	to	recharge	and	rest. We	employ	a	hybrid	work	model	in	certain	countries,	giving	our	employees	the	flexibility	to	work	offsite	or	at	onsite	Cisco locations.

## Employee	Development

We	know	careers	are	not	static	pathways	that	look	the	same	for	everyone.	We	also	know	that	the	world	of	work	will	continue	to rapidly	evolve,	requiring	new	skillsets.	At	Cisco,	we	believe	that	your	career	is	owned	by	you,	supported	by	your	leader,	and enabled	by	Cisco.	Cisco	believes	in	open-ended	self-directed	learning,	understanding	that	each	individual	knows	best	what skills	and	resources	they	need	to	succeed.	This	means	that	while	each	employee	has	the	power	to	shape	their	career	on	their own	 terms,	 they	 also	 have	 a	 supportive	 ecosystem	 to	 develop	 the	 skills	 they	 need	 to	 succeed	 both	 today	 and	 tomorrow. questions.question: How has Texas Instruments' strategic emphasis on Embedded Processing Products evolved from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of its role within the company's four sustainable competitive advantages?
questions.answer: From 2022 through 2024, Texas Instruments consistently emphasized Embedded Processing Products as a core component of its business model, maintaining its position as the second of four sustainable competitive advantages. In 2022, the company described the broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products as offering 'more opportunity per customer and more value for our investments.' This language remained consistent in 2023 and 2024, with identical phrasing used each year to describe the value derived from the product portfolio. While the strategic framing remained stable, the repeated emphasis over three consecutive years underscores the sustained importance of Embedded Processing Products in TI's long-term value creation model, particularly in enabling deeper customer engagement and diversified returns on investment.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## ITEM 7. Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations

## Overview

We design, make and sell semiconductors to electronics designers and manufacturers all over the world. Technology is the foundation of our company, but ultimately, our objective and the best metric to measure progress and generate long-term value for owners is the growth of free cash flow per share.

Our strategy to maximize free cash flow per share growth has three elements:

1. A great business model that is focused on analog and embedded processing products and built around four sustainable competitive advantages. The four sustainable competitive advantages are powerful in combination and provide tangible benefits:
- i. A strong foundation of manufacturing and technology that provides lower costs and greater control of our supply chain.
- ii. A broad portfolio of analog and embedded processing products that offers more opportunity per customer and more value for our investments.
- iii. The reach of our market channels that gives access to more customers and more of their design projects, leading to the opportunity to sell more of our products into each design and gives us better insight and knowledge of customer needs.
- iv. Diversity and longevity of our products, markets and customer positions that provide less single point dependency and longer returns on our investments.

Together, these competitive advantages help position TI in a unique class of companies capable of generating and returning significant amounts of cash for our owners. We make our investments with an eye towards longterm strengthening and leveraging of these advantages.

2. Discipline in allocating capital to the best opportunities. This spans how we select R&D projects, develop new capabilities like TI.com, invest in new manufacturing capacity or how we think about acquisitions and returning cash to our owners.
3. Efficiency, which means constantly striving for more output for every dollar spent.

We believe that our business model with the combined effect of our four competitive advantages sets TI apart from our peers and will for a long time to come. We will invest to strengthen our competitive advantages, be disciplined in capital allocation and stay diligent in our pursuit of efficiencies. Finally, we will remain focused on the belief that long-term growth of free cash flow per share is the ultimate measure to generate value.

Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (MD&A) should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the related notes that appear elsewhere in this document. In the following discussion of our results of operations:

- Our segments represent groups of similar products that are combined on the basis of similar design and development requirements, product characteristics, manufacturing processes and distribution channels, and how management allocates resources and measures results. See Note 1 to the financial statements for more information regarding our segments.
- When we discuss our results:
- Unless otherwise noted, changes in our revenue are attributable to changes in customer demand, which are evidenced by fluctuations in shipment volumes.
- New products do not tend to have a significant impact on our revenue in any given period because we sell such a large number of products.
- From time to time, our revenue and gross profit are affected by changes in demand for higher-priced or lower-priced products, which we refer to as changes in the 'mix' of products shipped.
